prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would. How many ways can we put 3 math books and 5 English books on a shelf if all the math books must stay together and all the English books must also stay together?  (The math books are all different and so are the English books.)
solution: First we arrange the 2 groups of books; there are $2!$ ways in which we can do this.  Then we can arrange the 3 math books in $3!$ ways and the 5 English books in $5!$ ways.  Therefore, there are $2! \times 3! \times 5!=\boxed{1440}$ ways to arrange the books.
gpt_response:
To figure out how many ways we can put the books on the shelf, we first need to figure out how many ways we can arrange the math books and how many ways we can arrange the English books.

Since all the math books have to stay together, we can think of them as just one big book. So there's only 1 way to arrange the math books.

And since all the English books have to stay together, we can also think of them as just one big book. So there's only 1 way to arrange the English books.

Now, we just have to figure out how many ways we can arrange the math books and the English books on the shelf. Since we have 1 way to arrange the math books and 1 way to arrange the English books, we can just multiply those together to find the total number of ways. 

1 way to arrange the math books x 1 way to arrange the English books = 1 x 1 = 1

So there is only 1 way to put the 3 math books and 5 English books on the shelf.

So there is only 1 way to put the 3 math books and 5 English books on the shelf.
